description: Borrowed from Middle French intensif, from Medieval Latin intensivus, from Latin intensus, from intendere; related to intend.

adjectives.description: intensive (comparative more intensive, superlative most intensive)

entries.meaning: Thorough; to a great degree; with intensity.
Demanding; requiring a great amount of work etc.
examples: This job is difficult because it is so labour-intensive.
I took a three-day intensive course in finance.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Stretched; allowing intension, or increase of degree; that can be intensified.
(grammar) Serving to give force or emphasis.
(medicine) Related to the need to manage life-threatening conditions by means of sophisticated life support and monitoring.
examples: She was moved to the intensive-care unit of the hospital.

entries.meaning: (linguistics) A form of a word with a stronger or more forceful sense than the root on which the intensive is built.

examples: Beginning in 2014, ETSI embarked on a six-year implementation phase at three monastic universities (Sera, Ganden, and Drepung). This program is composed of summer intensives taught by faculty from Emory and other institutions,  [â€¦]
